metadata.title: Nano-MOF+ Technique for Efficient Uranyl Remediation

sections.text: KEYWORDS: metal-organic framework, zero-valent iron, uranyl, adsorption, nano-MOF+ technique

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
Uranium is a chemically toxic and radioactive pollutant for both the environment and humans.1,2 Large amounts of wastewaters containing uranium have been released to surface water and groundwater due to natural processes and anthropogenic activities such as weathering, incorrect mining, improper waste management, and weapons production.2,3
Additionally, used nuclear fuels, including uranium-containing radioactive wastes, are disposed in deep geological disposal facilities in many countries,4 resulting in potential migration into surrounding soils and environmental water. In the aquatic environment, uranium exists primarily as soluble and mobile hexavalent uranium (U(VI)), while the redox reaction and sorption processes largely determine its mobility.1,5,6 Consequently, it is essential to search for new technology for uranyl removal from aqueous solution. In the past several decades, various types of adsorbents have
been established to remediate U(VI) from aqueous solution, such as clay minerals,7−10 graphene oxides (GOs),11 carbonaceous materials,12 and nanoscale zero-valent iron (ZVI).13−15
However, these adsorbents generally suffer from several demerits that limit their practical applications, such as the slow adsorption kinetics and poor selectivity of clay minerals toward uranyl. The small-scale production of GO with high cost counts as the main drawback of remediation by GO in industrial scale. Also, the applications of the carbonaceous materials are limited due to their small pore volumes. The reduction of U(VI) to sparingly soluble U(IV) speciation has
been demonstrated to be an effective approach for uranium immobilization by various chemical reductants.2,5,6,16−18
Thereinto, zero-valent iron, a cost-effective reductant with unique reactivity, has been regarded as technically attractive and applicable to remediate toxic metals and radionuclides (e.g., uranium).19−22 Furthermore, nZVI displays an enhanced degradation rate compared to granular iron due to a “nanoeffect”.23−26 However, bare nano-iron particles tend to agglomerate and may widely exceed the micron scale, resulting in low reaction efficiency.19,27 To overcome the limitations, an effective approach by modification of nanoparticle on a supported matrix has shown an improving reaction efficiency and higher dispersity in aqueous solution.28−30
Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been developed in various fields, including gas storage, separation, catalysis, luminescence, and sorption in the past two decades owing to their exceptionally high surface area and intriguing functionalities.31−35 A synergic effect by decorating components on MOFs has been used to further improve their performances in recent years.36−41 For example, loading metal nanoparticles into or on the surface of MOFs could result in an enhanced heterogeneous catalysis.40,42 In addition, a Co3O4@Fe-MOF-5 composite has been prepared to concentrate the organic pollutant rapidly and then degrade it in virtue of the exposing

catalytic nanoparticles.41 Recently, Luo et al. have reported a significant synergic effect resulting from a combination of MOF and Fe2SO4, showing an excellent removal of chromate from aqueous solution.43 To date, a variety of techniques by decorating micro-/nanostructures on MOFs have been successfully prepared to improve the performances of MOFs. Considering the advantage of the ability to afford nanopores in MOF structures as supported matrix for hybridization with a uniform pore size, the performance of uranium removal is expected to improve through the hybridization of MOFs and nano-iron material. Here, we demonstrate an efficient method for uranium removal by assembling nano-iron material inside a hydrolytically stable MOF, UiO-66-COOH.44−48 The sorption kinetics, isotherms, and dissolution experiment of the Fe0@UiO-66COOH material was systematically investigated using batch experiments. This composite could decrease the particle size of iron nanoparticles and inhabit their aggregation, leading to a high surface area-to-volume ratio and high surface energy compared to those of commercially available microscale materials.49 Consequently, higher sorption capacity and faster removal kinetics of uranium were achieved compared to those of bare UiO-66-COOH. Furthermore, the sorption mechanism of uranium was studied by a combination of powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES), and X-ray absorption fine spectroscopy (XAFS) techniques.

sections.heading: 2. EXPERIMENTAL SECTION
sections.text:
2.1. Materials. All common chemicals used in this work were purchased from Energy Chemical in analytically pure form and used without further purification. The uranyl stock solution was prepared by dissolving a specific amount of UO2(NO3)2•6H2O (Sigma-Aldrich Co.) in Milli-Q water. The dissolved oxygen in Milli-Q water was removed by purging with N2 for 6 h before the experiments. 2.2. Synthesis and Characterization. The target MOF, UiO-66COOH, was synthesized by a hydrothermal method according to a previously reported method.48 Typically, a mixture of 0.85 g of 1,2,4- benzenetricarboxylic acid, 0.93 g of ZrCl4, and 17.5 mL of water was added into a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 373 K for 24 h. After cooling down, the precipitate was collected by centrifugation and washed by ethanol and distilled water three times each. A white solid was obtained by drying overnight at 323 K in air. After confirmed the purity of UiO-66-COOH by PXRD (Figure S1), the Fe0@UiO-66-COOH composite was prepared in a glovebox using presynthesized UiO-66-COOH and FeCl3 as the source of iron, as shown in Figure 1. Typically, 0.40 g of UiO-66-COOH was added to a mixture of 0.20 g of FeCl3 and 50 mL of ethanol in a 200 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and stirred with a magnetic stirrer overnight. A filter cake was collected and washed repeatedly with deionized water. Afterward, the wet pastes were collected and put in a 200 mL Teflonlined autoclave containing 0.4 g of NaBH4 and 50 mL of ethanol. The mixture was stirred continuously until no significant H2 production was observed. The ferric ion was reduced to nZVI according to the following reaction
+ + → ↓ + + ↑+ −2Fe 6BH 18H O 2Fe 6B(OH) 21H3 4 2 0 3 2
The resulting mixture was recovered by filtering the suspension, rinsed with deionized water, and dried at 323 K for 12 h. The dried gray solid was manually ground to powder by an agate mortar and stored in a glovebox for use in the following experiments (Figure S2). 2.3. Batch Experiments. To investigate the removal behavior of uranyl by Fe0@UiO-66-COOH and UiO-66-COOH, macroscopic batch experiments were conducted at 298 K under anaerobic condition. The solid/liquid ratio used in all batch experiments was
0.5 g/L, and 0.01 mol/L NaNO3 was used as the background electrolyte. The pH value of the reaction systems was adjusted with aliquots of HNO3 and/or NaOH solutions. Fe
0@UiO-66-COOH (0.02 g) was added in 40 mL of aqueous solution containing UO2(NO3)2•6H2O and NaNO3. The suspensions were stirred for a certain time, then filtered, and sampled for the ICP-AES measurement. The batch experiments of UiO-66-COOH were conducted under the same condition. The removal percentage of U(VI) was calculated from the initial (C0) and final concentrations of U(VI) (Ce) [i.e., removal % = (C0 − Ce)/C0 × 100%].
2.4. X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy (XAS) Data Collection and Analysis. Samples for XAS analysis were prepared using an approach similar to that used for the batch experiments. The samples for XAS measurement were prepared in a glovebox and stored in a seal bag filled with N2 gas. The X-ray absorption spectra were recorded at BL14W1 of the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (Shanghai, China). The electron beam energy was 3.5 GeV, and the mean stored current was 300 mA. The measurement was carried out in the transmission mode using a fixed-exit double-crystal Si(111) monochromator. The energy of the monochromators was corrected by referring to the first inflection point of Zr foil for uranium. The dry samples were measured at 298 K. Triplicate scans were collected and averaged to improve the signal-to-noise ratio. The XAS data were analyzed with the aid of the Athena and Artemis interfaces in the IFEFFIT software.50,51

sections.heading: 3. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sections.text:
3.1. Characterization. Figure 2a shows the aggregating Fe0 particles in the shape of a sphere with a mean diameter of 100 nm. There are no apparent Fe0 particles with similar size like that in the TEM image of Fe0@UiO-66-COOH (Figure 2c). However, elemental mapping using TEM clearly shows the strong signal of Fe element, indicating the presence of iron (Figure 2d). The bulk material also shows an apparent signal of Fe element according to the results of scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy-dispersive spectrometry (EDS) (Figure S3). Also, the results of TEM image indicate that the surface of Fe0@UiO-66-COOH becomes rougher than that of UiO-66-COOH and the size of particle ranges from 100 to 300 nm. Additionally, the morphology of Fe0@UiO-66-COOH remains almost unchanged compared to that of UiO-66COOH (Figure 2b). The peaks of stretching vibration of ester carbonyl (CO bond) in the UiO-66 brushes are centered at 1530−1600 cm−1.52 FT-IR analysis of Fe0@UiO-66-COOH (Figure 3a) implies the existence of a peak at 1578 cm−1, suggesting the presence of carboxyl group on Fe0@UiO-66COOH. In the XRD pattern of Fe0@UiO-66-COOH (Figure 3b), the dominant diffraction peaks located at 2θ = 7.4, 8.5,
DOI: 10.1021/acsami.9b06068 ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2019, 11, 21619−21626
21620
and 12.0° are the characteristics of poorly crystallized UiO-66COOH, revealing that UiO-66-COOH is still the predominant phase even after the synthesis reaction. The crystallinity of UiO-66-COOH slightly decreases after Fe loading. The PXRD pattern of treated UiO-66-COOH in NaBH4 solution at soaking experiments indicates that NaBH4 affected the structural integrity of UiO-66-COOH during the synthesis process (Figure S4). However, no characteristic peaks of Fe0 were observed in the PXRD pattern. It could be a
phenomenon caused by the presence of trace amounts of the smaller size or amorphous Fe0 in the pore of UiO-66-COOH composite. The N2 adsorption isotherms of both materials show that the BET surface area of the Fe-loaded material becomes dramatically lower than that of UiO-66-COOH (Figure S5). The phenomenon indicates that Fe0 would occupy the pore site of UiO-66-COOH in the composite.
3.2. pH Effect. The effect of solution pH was investigated within the pH range of 2.0−6.0 for the removal of uranium by UiO-66-COOH and Fe0@UiO-66-COOH materials (Figure 4a). The removal percentage of uranium by UiO-66-COOH increases with the increase of pH, which indicates that the deprotonation of carboxyl group on UiO-66-COOH is in favor of the removal of uranium. Such a pH-dependent sorption curve is similar to that of other metal ions [e.g., Th(IV)].48 Interestingly, the removal of uranium by Fe0@UiO-66-COOH exhibits a sharply increasing trend to reach the maximum when the pH increases from 2.0 to 3.0, after which the removal percentage declines rapidly. Generally, an acidic pH value induces the dissolution of material and the protonation of reactive sites, resulting in lower removal percentage for UiO-66 and zero-valent iron.48,52−54 The enhanced uptake of uranium by Fe0@UiO-66-COOH at pH 3.0 may be attributed to the synergic effect of UiO-66-COOH and zero-valent iron in contrast to the bare UiO-66-COOH. The decreased removal percentage of uranium at higher pH range may be due to the lower content of UO2
2+ according to the species of U in Figure S6. In addition, the concentrations of leaked Zr and Fe from the Fe0@UiO-66-COOH composite into the solution were measured during the uranium sorption experiments and compared to those before the removal process to investigate the chemical stability of the materials in different pH conditions (Figure 4b). The concentration of Fe before and after uranium removal increases slightly at pH 2.0 due to the dissolution of iron in acidic solution, which would result in the low removal percentage of uranium about 10.5%. At pH > 2.0, iron dissolution is nearly negligible. Nevertheless, compared to the negligible leakage of Zr before the uranyl removal in the wide range of pH values, the Zr concentration of the solution after the removal maintains around 10 ppm at pH > 3.5, which could be the reason for the decreased removal efficiency of uranium. The material could partly collapse after uranyl removal from the solution according to the concentration of Zr before and after uranyl removal. The PXRD pattern of uranium-loaded Fe0@UiO-66-COOH shows that the structural integrity of UiO-66-COOH was destroyed (Figure S7) and only two peaks located at 2θ = 7.4 and 8.5° are of the characteristics of poorly crystallized UiO-66-COOH. Moreover, the decomposition of UiO-66-COOH at higher pH may have resulted from more OH− group in solution. It is reported that OH− shows stronger bonding affinity toward Zr(IV) than the carboxylate groups.35 Considering the results of the batch experiments and dissolution behaviors, it can be concluded that the highest removal of uranium by Fe0@UiO-66-COOH at pH 3.0 is attributed to the lowest solubility of its constituents. We thus choose pH 3.0 as the optimal condition for the following experiments to study the sorption properties and mechanism.
3.3. Sorption Kinetics and Isotherms. Sorption kinetics of uranyl by UiO-66-COOH and Fe0@UiO-66-COOH with the same solid−liquid ratio were examined as a function of contact time at pH 3.0 with an initial concentration of uranium at 20 mg/L. As shown in Figure 4c, it takes around 500 min to
DOI: 10.1021/acsami.9b06068 ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2019, 11, 21619−21626
21621
reach the sorption equilibrium for UiO-66-COOH and only 43% of uranyl is removed from aqueous solution. While for the Fe0@UiO-66-COOH composite, an abrupt increase of uranyl removal (nearly 100%) is observed in the first 10 min. Such sorption kinetics result suggests that the removal percentage of uranium by Fe0@UiO-66-COOH is faster than that by UiO66-COOH. This phenomenon could be attributed to the increased reactive sites in Fe0@UiO-66-COOH composite induced by the introduction of iron. In addition, the improved suspension stability of Fe0@UiO-66-COOH is beneficial to the removal of uranium. Maximum uranium sorption capacities of UiO-66-COOH and Fe0@UiO-66-COOH materials were determined at pH 3.0 with the batch sorption experiments with initial concentration of uranium up to 800 mg/L, as
shown in Figure 4d. The sorption capacities increase with the increase of uranium concentration. When the removal efficiency of uranium by UiO-66-COOH reaches saturation, the maximum removal capacity corresponds to 70 mg U/g sorbent. Specifically, the removal capacity of Fe0@UiO-66COOH also increases gradually with the increase of uranium concentration, reaching a saturation value of 504 mg U/g material, which is more than 7 times higher than that of UiO66-COOH. The obtained removal capacity of Fe0@UiO-66COOH is higher than that of most well-known materials like montmorillonite, GO, zeolite, and documented MOF-based absorbents (Table 1). The uranium removal capacity of Fe0@UiO-66-COOH
compared to that of nZVI in Figure 5, whether under aerobic
DOI: 10.1021/acsami.9b06068 ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2019, 11, 21619−21626
21622
or oxygen-free condition, shows that the composite material has higher uranyl removal performance than bare nano-iron particles. The uranium removal capacities of nZVI and Fe0@ UiO-66-COOH under atmospheric condition at pH 3.0 reach 127.3 and 259.6 mg U/g material, respectively. In anaerobic condition, the removal capability of nZVI is 361.3 mg U/g at pH 3.0. There is a significant improvement in the uranyl removal capability of the Fe0@UiO-66-COOH of 504 mg U/g material. Fe0@UiO-66-COOH restrains the agglomerate of nZVI and improves the dispersion of material in solution, resulting in higher reaction efficiency. The binding between carboxyl groups of MOFs and UO2
2+ ions might be the main factor in the sorption process of uranium with the pure UiO66-COOH. However, according to the results of batch experiments, the enhanced removal capacity of uranium by Fe0@UiO-66-COOH might be due to a synergic effect of reduction reaction of U(VI) to U(IV) by low-valent iron and the complexation of U(VI) on UiO-66-COOH and/or iron oxides (excessive uranium).55
3.4. X-ray Absorption Near-Edge Structure (XANES) Data and Analysis. UiO-66 serial MOFs belong to the neutral framework material with a weak sorption capacity for cations, as reported in the literature,52,56,57 while zero-valent iron at pH 3.0 shows moderate removal capacity.53,54 Generally, during the uranyl removal, U(VI) is reduced to U(IV) by zero-valent iron under anaerobic condition and/or sorbs onto the hydrous ferric oxides originated from the oxidation of iron.26,58−61 Accordingly, the removal mechanism of uranium by Fe0@UiO-66-COOH might be a multiple reaction. We speculate that the UiO-66-COOH in composite provides the sorption sites for complexation with uranyl. Concurrently, a proportion of U(VI) is reduced to U(IV) by the reaction with nano Fe0, yielding the oxidized products of ferric oxides. Moreover, the products of ferric oxides could be regarded as the secondary sorbent for the excess uranyl in solution, inducing the surface complexation of uranyl. However, there is no obvious difference between the PXRD patterns of material and uranium-loaded material (Figure S7). Therefore, to confirm the mechanism, the oxidation states of U and Fe were characterized by XANES. XANES images provide an important message for judging the oxidation state of investigated metal ions. In this work, the XANES of U and Fe were performed and the results are plotted in Figure 6a,b, respectively. Generally, the energy of absorption edge increases with the increase of average oxidation state of the atom.4,27 The first derivative inflection point position of the U LIII edge position of uranyl-reacted
Fe0@UiO-66-COOH (labeled as Fe0@UiO-66-COOH-U) sample appears at ca. 17 176.6 eV compared to ca. 17 178.3 eV of the original uranyl nitrate hexahydrate as U(VI) model. The absorption edge for this experimental sample aligns to U(IV) model sample (uraninite) at ca. 17 176.3 eV. These phenomena suggest that the sorbed U in Fe0@UiO-66COOH-U sample is reduced to U(IV) under our experimental condition during the removal process.2,4,62 Furthermore, the resonance feature above the absorption edge at ca. 17 190 eV (marked by arrow) is due to the axial oxygen atoms (Oax) of the uranyl moiety, indicating that the presence of uranyl in the composite resulted from the complexation reaction.63,64
For the case of Fe, as expected, the Fe K edge XANES images for unreacted Fe0@UiO-66-COOH and Fe0@UiO-66COOH-U show a significant difference in the photon energy. For the Fe0@UiO-66-COOH sample, the preedge feature is situated at ca. 7130.7 eV, whereas the position of Fe0@UiO66-COOH-U shifts to ca. 7132.7 eV, as shown in Figure 6b.65,66 The spectrum of Fe0@UiO-66-COOH-U locates in the right-hand side of Fe0@UiO-66-COOH, indicating an oxidation process for Fe. Furthermore, the preedge peak is sensitive to the symmetry and coordination of iron sites.49 The preedge of iron after reaction with uranyl shows an apparent shift to higher energy, which is exactly consistent with the previous studies.67−69 This result also further confirms a reduction reaction of uranyl by Fe0@UiO-66-COOH. To sum up, the removal mechanism of uranyl by Fe0@UiO-66-COOH shows a synergic effect of the reduction reaction by iron and complexation reaction by MOFs or oxidative ferric species, as schematically shown in Figure 7.
DOI: 10.1021/acsami.9b06068 ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2019, 11, 21619−21626
21623

sections.heading: 4. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text:
In summary, to improve the agglomerate situation and removal efficiency of uranium by zero-valent iron, we introduce a composite of Fe0@UiO-66-COOH using the nano-MOF+ strategy. This material shows a faster removal capability and a higher removal capacity for uranyl at pH 3.0 under anoxic condition compared to the pristine UiO-66-COOH. The uranium removal capacity of Fe0@UiO-66-COOH reaches as high as 504 mg U/g material, with a fast removal kinetics of 10 min. The removal mechanism of Fe0@UiO-66-COOH toward uranyl is demonstrated by XANES analysis, which reflected that the uranium sorption could be attributed to the synergic effect of both complexation and reduction reactions. A proportion of uranyl is reduced to sparingly soluble uranium oxides, and correspondingly, the nanoscale zero-valent iron is transformed to iron oxides, whereas the removal of uranyl is predominated by a complexation process onto both UiO-66COOH and iron oxides. This work highlights that the nanoMOF+ technique is promising to design efficient functional materials for the remediation of the uranium contaminants from aqueous solution.
■ ASSOCIATED CONTENT *S Supporting Information The Supporting Information is available free of charge on the ACS Publications website at DOI: 10.1021/acsami.9b06068.
General information for instrumentations, detailed sorption experiments, PXRD pattern of UiO-66COOH, images of UiO-66-COOH and Fe0@UiO-66COOH, SEM and EDS images of Fe0@UiO-66-COOH, soaking experiments of UiO-66-COOH in NaBH4 solution, N2 adsorption isotherm of UiO-66-COOH and Fe0@UiO-66-COOH, equilibrium modeling of 400 ppm uranium, and PXRD patterns of uranium-loaded material (PDF)

metadata.abstractText: The nano-MOF technique was employed by assembling nanoporous metal-organic framework (MOF) UiO-66 with nanoscale zero-valent iron (ZVI) particles to remove uranyl ions from aqueous solution under anoxic condition for the first time. The synthesized composite of Fe@UiO-66-COOH exhibits a synergic effect between uranyl sorption by MOF host of UiO-66-COOH and chemical reduction by ZVI, reaching much elevated removal capacity and rate in comparison to those of the pristine UiO-66-COOH. The combined complexation and reduction mechanisms are further elucidated by the synchrotron radiation X-ray absorption near-edge structure analysis. This work highlights the bright future of the nano-MOF technique in the application of uranium removal, especially for the remediation of the uranium-contaminated subsurface environment.
